text:
Hi everyone, and welcome to this AWS
breakout session.
My name is Mohit Gupta.

I lead the product management for AWS
Wavelength.
AWS Wavelength is the mobile edge compute
which resides within the 5G network.

And today we're going to talk about
how AWS Wavelength
is combining with network API

and helping the next generation
of applications.

I have an illustrious panel here with me
so without much ado,

let's dive in
and get a quick round of introduction.

So customer
first, let's start with you, Antonio.

Why don’t you tell about yourself,
your company, and the project.
What is exciting about this?

Well, at CINFO we are a company
specialized in video technology

for telcos, media, sports,
public administration industries.

Our specific job
is to apply artificial intelligence

to live video inputs
that we receive from the field.
We perform automatically with production.
And that means that we have to manage
the reception of video

analyzing and then return commands to
the field in a very quick response time.

We have cloud nodes in Europe,
in Asia, in America, so all over AWS
infrastructure.

And when Telefónica offers us
the opportunity

to jump into this project to accelerate
the performance of the system, we jump.
I'm very excited.
Great.
Thank you so much. Over to you, David.
So I'm David del Val.

I am responsible for the Open Gateway
project at Telefónica.

Open Gateway is an industry wide
initiative of all the telcos in the world

to expose our capabilities, network
capabilities, using APIs

so that developers
such as CINFO can take advantage
of, you know, how to control the network.
So one of the main APIs

that CINFO is using through
AWS is the Quality On-Demand

API that enables them
to transmit the video to the wavelength

in a very controlled manner
and with very high quality.
That’s great.
Over to you, Jaime.
Hello, my name is Jaime Diez.
I'm the Head of Engineering

for mobile private networks
and its computing at Vodaphone Business.

And what we have launched with AWS
are couple of countries, UK and Germany,

and we are working on a few more
that soon will be public.

And to me, specifically,
I'm very pleased to see how we are

helping customers to the use cases
that we are unveiling within.
And as a software engineer,

the fact that we are removing barriers
to leverage the network and compute.
So very happy to be here.
Awesome, thank you.

And finally, Asif. 
Hi, my name is Asif.

I lead engineering for Wavelength Network
APIs as a special project, and I worked

with Antonio’s team, David's team,
and Jaime’s team to get this pilot going.
So why don't we start with you, David.

So we have been within the telco
community,

have been talking
about exposure of network capabilities.
So what is special now?
What has changed?
Why are we so excited this time?

Well, first of all, we have 5G,
which we didn't before. And 5G

was designed from the ground
up to enable more speed, less latency,

but also more ease
of exposing capabilities.

We have the network exposure
function in 5G

that kind of takes all the complexity
and exposes,

to software
developers, the capabilities of 5G.

And on top of that,
we are building another abstraction layer

that makes it really easy for developers
with one single line of code,

as we say,
to actually get to these capabilities.

So first this,
you know, the basic capability of 5G

and the ability
to expose it in a very simple way.
Secondly, we have all the telcos on board.

We have 20 telcos right now
that have signed an agreement among us
to all collaborate and have the same APIs

exposed to developers,
so that developers don't go crazy

just developing for Telefónica,
for Vodafone, Vodafone

and Telefonica
will have exactly the same APIs.
And I think that's that's very remarkable.
And third,

we are collaborating
with you guys, with AWS, you have this

fantastic developer ecosystem—developers
are used to your environment
and that's where

we want to expose this API
so that they find them and they say, “Oh,

I can control the network,
let's try it.” That's great.
Yeah, that's great.

So Asif, what is the importance of network
API to AWS?
How does it matter?
That's a great question, Mohit.

I think when you look at applications
and user experiences right now

in 2023, users want that seamless enhanced
user experience

that they get used to in,
the people who grew up in the mobile age,

and network APIs
allows us that quality of service, quality

on demand to hand it to the app developers
so when I open an application,

when I'm using an application,
I get that consistency over the radio,

that Telefónica provides
or a telco will provide

and the guarantee of the backbone
that AWS provides.

And you also land in the closest
Wavelength zone.

So you're optimizing on multiple factors
on the radio,
on location, and also on the backbone.

So it really allows for that
superlative experience to get to end users

who are playing games or in this case
video streaming

and also the developer experience
that David touched on.

How do we make this super, super simple
and consumable

by app developers that they can just,
with one line of code, get this going?

So I think network
APIs is a real game changer in

how we will experience our applications
as we move on

with a much higher user experience
and really great experience.

Great,
that's that's really wonderful to know.
So back to Antonio then.

Based on this collaboration that AWS
and Telefónica did for that project

that we we now have a proof point of how
we were able to improve the experience.

What does it mean
from a business perspective to you?
How does it help you in your business?
For us it's all important.

We are actually,
CINFO is, a spinoff of a telco company.

We design our products for a world where
5G is widespread or fiber is widespread.
In the pastl
we tested to deploy

our technology on the edge
computing on several telco infrastructure,

but it was very complicated,
a nightmare—security problems, firewalls,

even connectivity
from the outside world to the edge.
So in this project we have
the best of both worlds.

We have all the investment,
we have executed to integrate with AWS

and to be able to be elastic
and quick on reaction time.

In a given weekend
we can raise 200 machines, 300 machines
to serve our customers.

And then we have the other world,
the APIs of the network

and the aim and the capacity
to control the quality of the service

or to demand from the network
a better service.

So for us, or for me,
I expect easiness of the scale.
I can now launch this application in Asia,

if there is a telco data center
from you guys

with the capacity
of having good quality on that area,

which in a sense, would be impossible
for me to reach that telco operator

and to make an agreement
with each of one individually.

So for us, it’s
a big opportunity for scaling.
That's that's great to hear.
So back to you,

Jaime, you as Vodafone has been
our longstanding partner on Wavelength.
So we are coming making strides now.

How do you see what do you think
we should do to make this

collaboration
even faster, more innovative?
What are your thoughts on that?

I think we need to continue on the
on this same alliance.

From a technology perspective, continue
to combine the power of 5G

and Wavelength
and combining that network and compute

removing barriers
and removing friction.

Then continue to create awareness
for both customers

that perhaps in the past
didn't have a good experience

and they have forgot about the possibility
of actually doing something
and then offering to them.

Also awareness with developers
that perhaps are not aware of how easy

for them it is now to tap into the network
and into compute as previously.

And then thirdly,
I think continue expanding our footprint.
Today we are in UK and Germany,

but we really want to make this
totally ubiquitous as our networks are.

And we want to make it available for all
the developers and customers out there.

That's a great insight
that all of you provided.

It's really interesting
to listen to all the perspectives.

So I guess the key takeaway
which I get from this is three points.

One, we need to innovate,
bring the best of both worlds,

as you said, Antonio,
of bringing the compute,
all the amazing cloud services along with

now the programmability of the 5G network
and combining it together.

The second thing which I heard
was simplifying the experience.

How can we make sure that the developer
don't have to spend time and energy

in actually building, deploying
and getting to the APIs,

getting through all the constructs,
but a simple experience for them.

And third, most importantly,
how can we scale, as I said, I mean,

how can we scale it
beyond just one country globally?

Have you reached all your customers
around the globe?

So thank you so much.
This is really exciting.

Really looking forward to working
with all of you on next exciting projects.
Thank you. Thank you.
